data.title: What happened to the cast of BBC sitcom Only Fools and Horses
data.meta_description: As Only Fool's and Horses approaches its 40th anniversary, we take a look at what the actors of the hit sitcom are up to now
data.text:
The UK has produced some of the most successful comedy shows of the last century.

While American sitcoms are great for a bit of light-watching, they don't quite get you belly-laughing in quite the same way that British comedies do.

From timeless classics such as Dad's Army and Fawlty Towers, to modern triumphs like Peep Show and The Office, UK comedy is golden.

Read more: What happened to the cast of police drama The Bill

But arguably the best comedy show to have come out of this country is the iconic Only Fools and Horses.

Set in Peckham, southeast London, John Sullvian's Only Fools and Horses follows market trader Derek 'Del Boy' Trotter and his younger brother Rodney on their mission to get rich quick.

The legendary show holds the record for the highest UK audience for a sitcom episode - with 24.3 million viewers tuning in for the episode 'Time on Our Hands' in 1996.

Only Fools and Horses was so popular it even had a number of spin-off shows, including The Green Green Grass, prequel Rock & Chips and a musical adaptation in 2019.

The original series came to an end in 1991 but the BBC produced a number of specials until it finally finished in 2003.

The success of the BBC series was undoubtedly made by its star studded cast, but what happened to the actors behind the characters we came to know and love?

As Only Fools and Horses approaches its 40th anniversary, KentLive takes a trip down memory lane to find out what the cast are up to now.

Derek 'Del Boy' Trotter - Sir David Jason

Charismatic, sweet-talking Del Boy was one of the most iconic characters in the history of television, but a horrifically bad salesman.

Nevertheless he was always out trying to scam someone into buying his dodgy goods, including 'Peckham Spring Water' which was just bottled water from his tap.

Sir David Jason had multiple roles before he took on the character of Del Boy, but it was Only Fools and Horses that really made his career.

Despite being considered for the part late on, he made it his own - bringing in Del Boy's tacky gold jewellery and trademark camel coat.

Jason has won numerous awards for his acting career, including being knighted for services to acting and comedy in 2005.

His last major roles have included being Detective Inspector Jack Frost, which he retired from in 2010, and returning for Still Open All Hours in 2013.

Life hasn't always been 'cushty' for Jason, whose long-term girlfriend Myfanwy Talog died of breast cancer in 1995.

But things started to look on the up for the actor after he became a father for the first time at the age of 61, when his 41-year-old girlfriend Gill Hinchcliffe, gave birth to baby Sophie Mae in 2001.

The pair married in 2005 and live as a family in Buckinghamshire.

In his free time, Jason is a patron of the Shark Trust, a regsitered charity working to advance the conservation of sharks through science, education, influence and action.

He is also Honorary Vice Patron of the Royal International Air Tattoo and a qualified helicopter pilot.

In 2017, it was reported that a "credible threat" was made to Jason's life, although it has not emerged why he was targeted.

Rodney Trotter - Nicholas Lyndhurst

Del Boy's awkward and naïve younger brother Rodney was always eager to steer clear of his brother's get-rich-quick plans.

The innocent side kick, who acted as Del Boy's dogsbody, was often the punchline of the joke and, much like his older brother, never had much luck with the ladies as a result.

But he did eventually settle down with Cassandra, who he went on to marry.

Nicholas Lyndhurst has starred in a range of other popular sitcoms, a far cry from his Peckham character, including Goodnight Sweetheart, The Two of Us and After You've Gone.

Outside the world of showbiz, Lyndhurst's hobbies include underwater diving, beekeeping and piloting his own aeroplanes.

He lives in West Wittering in West Sussex with his wife Lucy, a former ballet dancer, who he married in 1999.

Their son, Archie followed in his father's footsteps as an actor, appearing as Ollie Coulton in CBBC comedy series So Awkward.

However the 19-year-old died in his sleep from a brain haemorrhage caused by acute lymphoblastic lymphoma/leukaemia earlier this year.

Lyndhurst shared the heartbreaking loss in a statement reading: "Lucy and I are utterly grief stricken and respectfully request privacy."

Grandad - Lennard Pearce

Unfortunately the legendary character Grandad from the hit BBC series never made it to the end of filming, after he tragically passed away from a heart attack, aged 69, in 1988.

Despite spending most of the show in his armchair, Grandad was a well-loved character, who was sadly missed after Pearce's untimely death.

But the actor had already had a successful career prior to the show, working alongside the likes of Laurence Olivier and Anthony Hopkins in theatre productions.

Uncle Albert - Buster Merryfield

After Pearce's death in 1988, Uncle Albert was introduced to the Trotter household to replace him

Buster Merryfield surprisingly didn't have much acting experience, only becoming a professional actor at the age of 57, but he was chosen based on his iconic white beard, which became fondly associated with the character of Unc.

The estranged brother of the Trotter's late Grandad, Uncle Albert could often be heard reminiscing about his career in the Royal Navy during the wartime.

Merryfield was just as much the comedian in real life - in 1997 he fell over at the British Comedy Awards while walking to the stage to collect an award for David Jason.

Despite cutting his forehead, he continued on and collected the award.

Sadly, Merryfield also never made it to see the end of Only Fools and Horses, tragically dying at the age of 78 in 1999 as a result of a brain tumour.

His death was written into the series as a tribute - possibly one of the only serious moments in the comedy's history.

Raquel Turner - Tessa Peake-Jones

The character of Raquel was only meant to have a one-off appearance, as the writers wanted more female characters on-screen.

But she soon became a permanent character after the production team thought she'd make a good love interest for Del Boy.

The pair had their fair share of ups and downs, but they eventually settled down and had a son, Damien.

The actress has since gone on to appear in various British TV shows, including Midsomer Murders, Doctors, Casualty, Holby City and Doctor Who.

She made headlines recently after it emerged she married her on-screen son, who was played by Douglas Hodge.

The couple have two children together, Mollie Rose and Charlie, but unfortunately split in February 2013 after being married for 27 years.

Trigger - Roger Lloyd-Pack

The 'village idiot' character Trigger was best known for always failing to get Rodney's name right - instead calling him Dave.

Roger went on to get leading roles in an array of TV shows, including The Vicar of Dibley, Doctor Who and US drama The Borgias.

He also went on to star in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, in which he played the role of Barty Crouch Snr.

Lloyd-Pack was married twice - first to Sheila Ball and then to the poet and dramatist Jehane Markham.

He had a daughter, actress Emily Lloyd, and three sons, and lived in Kentish Town, north London.

In his spare time Lloyd-Pack supported Tottenham Hotspur - even voicing the pre-match build-up montage video shown ahead of all Tottenham Hotspur's home matches, which is still played today.

Sadly, the popular actor died from pancreatic cancer in 2014 at the age of 69.

Co-stars David Jason and Nicholas Lyndhurst were amongst those who attended his funeral.

Boycie - John Challis

Car salesman Boycie was just as untrustworthy as Del Boy, but a lot less likeable.

Despite spending most of the time boasting about his wealth, the character was so popular he went on to continue the role in Only Fools and Horses spin-off, The Green Green Grass.

The comedy show followed Boycie and his wife Marlene as they went on the run from a criminal gang.

Challis has continued to pursue his actor career since the end of Only Fools and Horses and the subsequent spin offs.

He's since gone on to have roles in Doctors, Are You Being Served and Benidorm.

Challis' personal life is almost as eventful as his characters - having been divorced three times and married four times.

He has no children but currently lives with his fourth wife Carol in Herfordshire.

Challis is a patron of the British Hedgehog Preservation Society and an Arsenal supporter, when he isn't acting.

He recently wrote two autobiographies but had to cancel his book tour this year after his management revealed he had been living with a secret cancer diagnosis since 2019.

Marlene Boyce - Sue Holderness

Boycie's wife Marlene didn't appear on the show until 1985.

It was often implied that she might have been romantically involved with all of her husband's friends and there were even rumours that Del Boy was the father of the pair's child.

Actress Sue Holderness only appeared in 20 episodes of Only Fools and Horses but went on to reprise the role in the spin-off The Green Green Grass.

She has also appeared in a variety of UK shows, including Doctors, Casualty, Still Open All Hours and Cold Feet.

She recently joined the cast of EastEnders as newcomer Estelle.

Sue keeps her personal life relatively private, but has made regularly appearances in pantomime shows throughout her career.

Denzil Tulser - Paul Barber

Liverpudlian lorry-driver Denzil was a loveable character who was often the victim of Del Boy's scams.

Actor Paul Barber had a tough start in life after he was taken into care at the age of seven, following the death of his mother from tuberculosis.

His father died when Barber and his siblings were very young.

Whilst he was in care, he was abused both physically and mentally - he noted that he has suffered like others, but channeled his emotions into acting.

After Only Fools and Horses Barber went on to appear in a number of UK shows include Brookside, and the classic male stripper comedy film, The Full Monty.

He is still working today - recent credits include CBBC children’s show The Dumping Ground, Casualty and Death in Paradise.

In July 2011 Barber, who lives in Essex, was awarded an honorary doctorate from Liverpool John Moores University for "outstanding contribution to the performing arts".

Cassandra Trotter - Gwyneth Strong

Gwyneth Strong played Rodney's girlfriend Cassandra, who he eventually married at the end of series six.

The actress has since enjoyed success in the world of TV and film - appearing in Casualty and Doctors, while also playing the recurring role of Geraldine Clough on EastEnders since 2016.

She also has an impressive number of stage credits - including the role of Kath Casey in a 2008 West End production of Madness’s Our House.

Gwyneth has been married to Footballers’ Wives star Jesse Birdsall since 2000 and they have two children together, Oscar and Lottie.

Mickey Pearce - Patrick Murray

Mickey Pearce was famous for having a way with women - which often led to him running off with Rodney's girlfriends.

The arrogant character was prone to making exaggerated claims about his business success and prowess with the ladies.

Actor Patrick Murray landed a couple of big parts following the success of Only Fools and Horses, including in films Curse of the Pink Pather and The Firm, but he has since retired.

Murray has pursued a range of careers since, including a cabbie in Kent, a builder for a period of time and even a professional poker player at one point.

The actor is a staunch supporter of Millwall F.C., often being recognised whilst sitting in the stands.

In September 2017, Murray made headlines after it emerged that he would be separated from his Thai wife and their daughter Josie following a visa row.

The Home Office had denied a visa to his wife and daughter on the grounds he didn’t earn enough money to support them.

In 2018, Murray was supposed to take part in a bus trip that would raise money for Demelza, a children's hospice in Kent.

However, the trip was called off last minute after Murray revealed he is receiving treatment for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

He hopes to complete the trip later this year, which will see him entertain 70 fans while travelling from Leysdown-on-Sea in Kent to Margate.

Sid - Roy Heather

Sid owned a derelict cafe in Peckham in Only Fools and Horses, but eventually went on to become the landlord of local pub The Nag's Head.

While fighting in the Second World War he was captured then escaped, only for his boat to be sunk by a Greek fishing trawler being steered by Uncle Albert.

He may have only appeared in 13 episodes, but Heather clocked up an impressive CV of TV credits following the show, including The Bill, My Family, Birds of a Feather and Bottom.

Sadly, Roy died on 3 September 2014 aged 79 of undisclosed causes.

Mike - Kenneth MacDonald

Dim-witted landlord of The Nags Head, Mike Fisher, was another character who was often subjected to Del Boy's scams and constantly struggled to get him to pay off his bar tab.

Actor Kenneth MacDonald, left school at eighteen to help support his mother Emily, taking a job at a Kellogg's cornflakes factory.

Determined to pursue a career in acting, during night shifts he would perform Hamlet and other Shakespeare plays that he had learned at school.

He also took on the role as Gunner "Nobby" Clark in BBC sitcom, It Ain't Half Hot Mum and appeared in the Channel 4 soap Brookside.

Unfortunately Actor Kenneth MacDonald died unexpectedly of a heart attack in 2001 aged just 50 while on holiday with his family in Hawaii.

On hearing of MacDonald's death, Only Fools And Horses star David Jason said: "It is a terrible shock.

"It is like losing a member of the family, because he was one of the warmest, kindest people that I have had the good fortune to meet in my career."
